description: Borrowed from Latin cloāca (“sewer”), from cluō (“cleanse; purge”).

examples: The Thames, polluted with the filthy effusions of the cloacae.

entries.meaning: (zoology) The duct in reptiles, amphibians and birds, as well as most fish and some mammals, which serves as the common outlet for urination, defecation, and reproduction.
examples: In birds the rectum, at the termination of its canal, forms an oval or elongated pouch  […]  and then expands into a cavity, which has been named cloaca.

entries.meaning: (anatomy) A duct through which gangrenous material escapes a body.
examples: Across this shell [sc. of bone] small holes are eaten, by which the matter escapes, and which are called cloacae (Weidmann).
